question:
## Problem 1
Propose mechanisms for the first four reactions in the chapter.
<!-- Media -->
<!-- figureText: 2. \( {\mathrm{H}}^{ + },{\mathrm{H}}_{2}\mathrm{O} \) -->
`CCC(=O)CCC(=O)OCCCCC(C)(C1=CC=CC=C1)O.CCCC(=O)OOCC(C)(C)C(CCCOC(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1)[R10].CC(C)C(CCCOC(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1)(O)[R].CCCCC1(CCCCC1)O.CCCCC1(CCCCC1)O.CC1=CC=CC(=C1)C(CC=C)(O)[R].C(=C\OOC(=O)C1=CC=CC=C1)/CCl.C(=C\OOC=O)/CCl`
answer:
## Suggested solution
Each reaction involves nucleophilic attack of organometallic reagents on aldehydes/ketones followed by protonation. Allyl-lithium may attack through either end due to its ambident nature.
<!-- Media -->
`CC(CC1CCCCC1)C(C2CCCCC2)([O-])[O-].[Mo+4]`

question:
## Problem 2
When this reaction is carried out with allyl bromide labelled as shown with \( {}^{13}\mathrm{C} \), the label is found equally distributed between the ends of the allyl system in the product. Explain how this is possible. How would you detect the \( {}^{13}\mathrm{C} \) distribution in the product?
<!-- Media -->
`C(=O)OC(O)[Pb].C=CO[Bi].[73Br].[77Br]`
answer:
## Suggested solution
Allyl Grignard reagents can react at either end due to resonance. \( {}^{13}\mathrm{C} \) distribution is detected via NMR spectroscopy (115-120 and 45-50 ppm).
<!-- Media -->
`C=CC(=O)OC(C)(C)C1=CC=C(C=C1)OC(O)O`

question:
## Problem 3
What products would be formed in these reactions?
<!-- Media -->
`CC(C)(C)C#N.[C-]#N`
answer:
## Suggested solution
Ethyl Grignard acts as a base toward the alkyne. Organometallic addition to carbonyl groups occurs without allylic ambiguity.
<!-- Media -->
`C(#COCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCOCCCOCCOCCOCCOC`

question:
## Problem 4
Supers: alternative routes to fenarimol - that is, routes different from the one shown in the = 0.216).
<!-- Media -->
`C1=CC(=C(C=C1)Cl)C(C2=CC=C(C=C2)Cl)(C3=CN=CN=C3)O`
answer:
## Suggested solution
Alternative routes involve Grignard/organolithium addition to ketones. Bromine is replaced by metals (Li/MgBr) for nucleophilic attack.
<!-- Media -->
`C1=C(C=CC(=C1)Cl)C(=O)C2=CN=CN=C2`

question:
## Problem 5
The synthesis of the gastric antisecretory drug rioprostil requires this alcohol. (a) Suggest possible syntheses starting from ketones and organometallics and (b) suggest possible syntheses of the ketones in part (a) from aldehydes and organometallics.
<!-- Media -->
`CCCCCCCC/C=C\CCCCCCCCCC(CCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCC`
answer:
## Suggested solution
Three one-step syntheses from ketones/organometallics. Ketones are made via oxidation of alcohols (from aldehydes/organometallics).
<!-- Media -->
`CCCC(C)(CC#C)O.C#CCC(=O)CCC`

question:
## Problem 6
Suggest two syntheses of the bee pheromone heptan-2-one.
<!-- Media -->
`CC(=O)N=NC(CCCCN=NC(C)(CC(CCCCCC(=O)[X])O)CC(C)(C(=O)NC)N=NC)[R]`
answer: ## Suggested solution\nSyntheses involve aldehyde + organometallic followed by oxidation. Example: propanal + ethyl Grignard → heptan-2-ol → oxidation to ketone.

question:
## Problem 7
... ou prepare these compounds using ortho-lithiation procedures?
<!-- Media -->
`CCN(CC)C(=O)C1=CC=C(C)C=C1C(C2=CC=CC=C2Br)O`
answer:
## Suggested solution
Ortho-lithiation adds side chains to activated aromatic rings. Oxidation converts intermediates to ketones.
<!-- Media -->
`CCCC(C1=CC(=CC=C1OC)OC)O`

question:
## Problem 8
Why is it possible to make the lithium derivative \( A \) by \( \mathrm{{Br}}/\mathrm{{Li}} \) exchange, but not the lithium derivative B?
<!-- Media -->
`C=C(C1=CC=CC=C1)Br.C=C(C1=CC=CC=C1)Cl`
answer: ## Suggested solution\nVinyl bromides form stable \( \mathrm{sp}^2 \) carbanions; tertiary alkyl bromides form unstable \( \mathrm{sp}^3 \) carbanions.

question:
## Problem 9
Comment on the selectivity shown in this Grignard addition reaction used in the manufacture of an antihistamine drug.
<!-- Media -->
`C1=CC=NC(=C1)C(C2=CC=C(C=C2)Cl)O`
answer:
## Suggested solution
Grignard forms at aryl bromide (not chloride). Nucleophilic attack occurs at carbonyl (not \( \mathrm{C=N} \)) due to electronegativity and aromaticity preservation.
<!-- Media -->
`C1=CC=C(C=C1)P(C2=CC=CC=C2)C3=CC=CC=C3`

question:
## Problem 10
The antispasmodic drug biperidin is made by the Grignard addition reaction shown here. What is the structure of the drug?
<!-- Media -->
`C1CCC(CC1)C(CCN2CCCC2)(C3=CC=CC=C3)O`
answer:
## Suggested solution
Grignard reagent from alkyl bromide adds to ketone. Acidic workup yields tertiary alcohol (biperidin).
<!-- Media -->
`CC12CC(C1)C(CC2)C(CCN3CCCCC3)(C4=CC=CC=C4)O`

question:
## Problem 11
Draw a mechanism for this Grignard addition to a heterocyclic compound.
<!-- Media -->
`CN1C=CC=CC1CC2=CC=C(C=C2)OC`
answer:
## Suggested solution
Benzylic chloride forms Grignard, which adds to \( \mathrm{C=N^+} \). The + charge enhances electrophilicity.
<!-- Media -->
`COC1=CC=C(C=C1)CC2C=CC=CN2S(=O)(=O)C`
